title: (x) "Puerto Rico" board game typeface - Malvern {Mike F}
content:
I am trying to identify one of the typefaces used in the board game [<cite>Puerto Rico<cite></cite></cite>](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/www.boardgamegeek.com/game/3076). I've attached an image that contains examples that I've scanned in from various playing pieces and the game manual.

The best match I've been able to find so far is [Kynges X NF](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/nicksfonts/kynges-x-nf/) from [Nick's Fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/www.nicksfonts.com/). It's close, but not exactly the same.

According to that MyFonts page, Kynges X NF was "inspired by an offering in the 1938 classic, <cite>Letters and Lettering</cite> by Paul Carlyle and Gus Oring". Perhaps the face I'm looking for was digitized from the same source?

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Puerto Rico typeface.png](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/typophile.com/files/Puerto%20Rico%20typeface.png) | 17.86 KB |
author: Spire

comments.content:
Nick's version is awfully close - only a typographer would notice the differences, if there are any. Maybe the Puerto Rico type has the "t" crossbar a little heavier. What differences do you think you see?

Thanks for the pointer, btw. I had been wondering what typeface they were using, myself. Puerto Rico is a great game!

T

I too see lots of little differences.

The typeface appears in the Solotype Catalog as Yucca. Dan Solo created a digital version under a different name, for some reason: Malvern. It can only be had from the [24 Celtic and Medieval Display Fonts CD](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/store.doverpublications.com/0486999602.html) from Dover. I have Malvern and it is a perfect match.

Oops, there's the right foot of the "n" as well. That's pretty blatant.

T

Thanks for the help, guys. Malvern does appear to be a perfect match -- and quite a bargain, too.

As Mike has mentioned, there are many small differences between Kynges X NF and Malvern. Aside from the more glaring variations in form (such as the <cite>n</cite> that Thomas has pointed out), Malvern is on the whole more uniform and harmonious, while Kynges X NF is relatively uneven and idiosyncratic.

BTW, Thomas, you probably already know this, but just in case you were wondering about the _other_ face used heavily in <cite>Puerto Rico</cite>, it's [Post-Antiqua](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/www.bertholdtypes.com/bq_library/90092.html) from [Berthold](http://web.archive.org/web/20150419083518/http:/www.bertholdtypes.com/).

It's a great game indeed. And now that I know what faces to use, I'll be able to make my own authentic-looking custom building, resource, and even role pieces.

Yes Post-Antiqua was easy to recognize. But I had been wondering about the other typeface, that turns out to be Malvern. Thanks again.

T
